title: Most Long Island senators mum on gas moratorium, pipeline decision
text:
National Grid is refusing to process the requests for new gas hookups unless the state approves a controversial pipeline project by Williams, arguing that the natural gas line is necessary to address supply constraints. | AP Photo Most Long Island senators mum on gas moratorium, pipeline decision

ALBANY — As city officials in Brooklyn and Queens assail National Grid’s moratorium on new gas hookups in their boroughs, Long Island senators, whose constituents also are affected, have remained notably quiet about the issue.

National Grid has said nearly 3,000 applications for gas connections are currently stalled, representing 20,000 residential, multifamily and commercial units. Many of the applications come from Long Island developers or homeowners making renovations.

Story Continued Below

The utility is refusing to process the requests for new gas hookups unless the state approves a controversial pipeline project by Williams, arguing that the natural gas line is necessary to address supply constraints. Environmentalists, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo himself, question whether such constraints actually exist.

Although the moratorium affects Long Island, most of the region's state senators are declining to take an unequivocal public stance on the issue. County executives in both Nassau and Suffolk have endorsed the pipeline.

Long Island Senate races are among the most competitive in the state, and the region’s politics may make it difficult to take a firm position. The project is opposed by most environmental groups and backed by the Long Island Association, an influential business group, and politically powerful labor unions including the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York.

“Long Island is well known for its green politicians — Democrats and Republicans alike — and they know it can be a very complicated and dangerous landscape,” said Larry Levy, executive dean of the National Center for Suburban Studies at Hofstra University on Long Island.

The Democratic senators who played a key role in supporting the passage of the state’s climate bill should take a stand against the pipeline, said Ryan Madden of the Long Island Progressive Coalition.

“We’ve reached a turning point and we can’t be of two minds right now,” Madden said. “We have to stop the bad and build the new … We can’t pass monumental climate legislation only to go on locking ourselves into further emissions. I’d encourage them to take whatever perceived political risk there is and own the new future that we’re building that they helped usher.”

Long Island's Democratic state senators have been a key voting bloc on several issues since their party solidified control of the chamber this year. They opposed a measure to give driver’s licenses to undocumented immigrants, were wary of legalizing marijuana and were at the center of debate over ending a religious exemption for school vaccination requirements.

On this issue, many of the senators — Democrats and Republicans alike — have been anything but vocal. The offices of Sens. John Brooks (D-Nassau), Kevin Thomas (D-Nassau), Anna Kaplan (D-Nassau), Monica Martinez (D-Suffolk), Jim Gaughran (D-Suffolk) and Ken LaValle (R-Suffolk) did not return repeated requests for comment or interviews on the subject. The office of Sen. Todd Kaminsky, chairman of the Environmental Conservation Committee, did respond but declined to comment.

On Wednesday, a spokesperson for Sen. Phil Boyle (R-Suffolk) said he supports the pipeline.

Another exception to the rule of silence has been Senate Minority Leader John Flanagan, who represents a portion of Suffolk County. He took a clear public stance in support of the pipeline project on WCNY’s The Capitol Pressroom with Susan Arbetter last week.

“I blame the governor,” Flanagan said. “This was avoidable, this is still fixable. This is going to crush small business, it’s going to kill economic development.”

Brooks, although his office did not respond to POLITICO’s inquiries, wrote a letter in support of the pipeline in August 2019 to DEC Commissioner Basil Seggos. He cited the negative impacts of the moratorium on economic development projects.

“Without the [pipeline] project. I am concerned that Long Island residents and businesses are being denied the economic and environmental benefits that would come from this project as we transition to renewable energy,” he wrote.

Thomas signed on to a statement opposing federal changes to state pipeline permitting authority that cited previous opposition to the Williams pipeline. Gaughran publicly struggled with the issue at a town hall event, according to the Syosset Advance.

The Long Island senators could be taking a wait-and-see approach as the Department of Public Service investigates whether or not the moratorium is justified. Cuomo on Tuesday said that review would not be finished for “several weeks.”

“I know they want the pipeline approved and I hope they’re not pressuring government by excluding a lot of customers,” Cuomo told host Brian Lehrer on WNYC on Tuesday, citing cases where customers doing renovations have been unable to reconnect to gas service. “We’re against the pipeline. That’s our position … There’s no negotiation. If they’re extorting people and wrongfully turning off gas service, that’s a crime.”

The former president of the New York League of Conservation Voters endorsed the project, but current NYLCV president Julie Tighe, who was previously chief of staff at the state Department of Environmental Conservation, declined to comment directly on the issue.

“We believe coal and oil should be replaced as soon as possible by clean renewable energy sources but natural gas can be a bridge fuel that improves air quality and public health outcomes,” she said in a statement. “This quick and orderly transition will help us ensure energy reliability, affordability, and most importantly help us to achieve our carbon reduction goals, reduce air pollution, and improve public health now.”

DEC's review of the project, known formally as the Williams Northeast Supply Enhancement, does not take into consideration the moratorium or gas supply issues more broadly. Its authority to review the federally permitted pipeline stems from water quality impacts, and those issues were cited in March when DEC rejected the project.

Cuomo’s explicit opposition to the pipeline is a more aggressive stance than he’s previously taken. He typically defers more to DEC’s review process, which is ongoing after Williams resubmitted its application with additional information. The governor did mention that submission on WNYC.

DEC said in a statement a decision would be made on or before May 17, 2020.

“DEC subjects all applications for environmental permits to an extensive and transparent review process that encourages public input at every step,” the agency’s statement said.
description: The region’s politics may make it difficult to take a firm position.
